awd_abstract_narration:
SusChEM: Electrocatalysis with Butterfly [2Fe-2S] Clusters

The production of hydrogen, the simplest molecule, is a multi-billion dollar industry today that provides hydrogen primarily for combination with nitrogen to produce ammonia fertilizer needed to grow sufficient food for the world population, for removal of sulfur from fossil fuels, and for industrial applications needed to produce the materials for a modern society. Furthermore, one of the grand challenges facing the world today is the need for sustainable, clean, and cost-effective sources of energy and fuels. Hydrogen is a high energy fuel that on burning (or in fuel cells) simply has water as the exhaust product. Unfortunately 96% of the hydrogen produced today is obtained from the expensive action of extremely high temperature and pressure steam on hydrocarbons, a process that is wasteful of both energy and raw materials. Analysis shows that 2% of the world energy is used in these processes and half the world population would not be alive today without the process that uses hydrogen to produce fertilizer for food production. This research project, funded by the Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, is exploring the use of electricity to produce hydrogen directly from water in an efficient, clean and sustainable process. To effect the production of hydrogen from water at low temperature and pressure, an inexpensive, readily available catalyst is required. Professors Dennis L. Lichtenberger, Jeffrey Pyun and Richard S. Glass of the University of Arizona and Professor Dennis H. Evans of Purdue University are investigating the production of hydrogen from water using electricity and catalysts composed of inexpensive and plentiful iron and sulfur.

The catalysts in this study are inspired by an enzyme found in anaerobic bacteria that produces hydrogen from a [2Fe-2S] cluster site that has a structure denoted as a ?butterfly? type. Although the enzyme generates hydrogen very rapidly, the organometallic butterfly [2Fe-2S] clusters prepared in this project are orders of magnitude faster. The high rates of hydrogen production observed in this project indicate different factors are at play compared to both the biological enzyme and to other inorganic catalysts. This project is exploring the synthesis of new organometallic [2Fe-2S] cluster catalysts and investigating (1) the mechanism that allows for such fast electrocatalytic hydrogen production, (2) the incorporation of the [2Fe-2S] clusters into metallopolymers for increased water solubility and durability of the catalysts, and (3) approaches to achieve high stability of the reactive catalysts in air. The project combines expertise in synthetic organometallic chemistry, polymer chemistry, electrochemistry, and computational chemistry directed toward the fundamental understanding needed to devise efficient electrocatalytic production of molecular hydrogen from water, and educates students in the multidisciplinary and team approaches needed to address complex scientific challenges in the future.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
As has been stated, one of the grand challenges facing the world today is the need for sustainable, clean, and cost-effective sources of energy and fuels. Integral to this challenge is the need for hydrogen to store and utilize this energy, and a world-wide effort is ongoing to incorporate hydrogen in the energy economy. Our pursuit of the goals and specific aims of this research project has led to outcomes that are transformative for the development of electrocatalytic production of hydrogen from water. On the left in the figure is nature's enzyme for the production of hydrogen. To the right of the enzyme is our fully synthetic "artificial enzyme" for the production of hydrogen. Our artificial enzyme is composed of a polymer bound to an iron-sulfur site that catalyzes the combination of protons and electrons to form the hydrogen molecule. We have found that this metallopolymer catalyst is 100% efficient at producing fifteen million molecules of hydrogen per single iron-sulfur site every minute, which is 25 times faster than nature's enzyme.

Intellectual merit: In the course of investigating the high rate of this catalysis we have discovered (1) the dynamic and electronic features of the iron-sulfur site that lead to the rapid attraction of electrons and protons to combine and produce hydrogen, (2) the chemical and physical features of the polymer that produce low energy requirements, fast catalysis, and long lifetimes for the catalytic process, and (3) a proton source, for which we have coined the term "protic buffer electrolyte" (PBE), that acts as a co-catalyst to accelerate the rate of hydrogen production up to a hundred times. The latter discovery could benefit a large number of current technologies. The research has been published in several high-profile journals as well as journals that are central to the community. The fundamental discoveries in this research have also led to intellectual property in the form of invention disclosures and patent applications. Taken together these discoveries point the way to a paradigm shift to a new class of electrocatalytic production of hydrogen from neutral water using earth abundant and inexpensive materials, in contrast to current PEM electrolysis cells that operate best with rare and expensive platinum catalysts, and alkaline electrolysis cells that operate in extremely caustic conditions.

Broader impacts: In addition to the benefits to society of clean energy and fuels, the success of this project has contributed by its nature to the development of human resources and the need for multidisciplinary and collaborative experts who are highly trained to address future technological challenges. Three  graduate students were awarded Ph.D. degrees in the course of this project, and twelve undergraduate students gained extensive research experience. Of special note is that the University of Arizona is one of only a few Research I and AAU universities to be designated a Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI). The University is also an institutional member of the American Association of University Women (AAUW). One graduate student served as President of the Program to Advance Women Scientists (PAWS), another graduate student served as Outreach Chair, and an undergraduate student in this project volunteered with the program. The undergraduate student was awarded the Outstanding Senior Award upon graduation. This project also gave a graduate student the opportunity to found the Women in STEM Student Council (WiSSC) at the University of Arizona, which has served to pair hundreds of undergraduate and graduate women with industry and academic professionals. This student has received several awards for her many contributions. All of the students were engaged in outreach through the ACS Science Coaches program for Title 1 elementary schools, through the Chemical Discovery program of science demonstrations for middle school students, through the Girls in Engineering, Mathematics, and Science (SEMS) program for middle school students, and much more.

 


Last Modified: 12/31/2021
Modified by: Dennis L Lichtenberger

Image
  • Our synthetic "artificial enzyme" metallopolymer is highly effective at hydrogen production from water.
    Dennis L Lichtenberger
    Copyright owner is an institution with an existing agreement allowing use by NSF
    Dennis L Lichtenberger
    Nature's enzyme vs. our metallopolymer catalyst,
